@chowkamlee81 thanks for reporting the problem. The example is fixed. Please check out the latest version and give it a try.

Also, note that you need to run the example with `example/gluon/` as the current working directory, so that `data` module can be correctly imported.
And feel free to close the issue if it's resolved.
Certain convolution layouts on CPU are not supported though API claims them to be supported (e.g. NWC NHWC NDHWC).

@yajiedesign  Thank you. Then i use the chapter 8 GPU example . It's found that GPU is 10 times faster than CPU.

Train vgg16 with two distribute machines (total 8 gpus).

python ../../tools/launch.py -n 2 --launcher ssh -H hosts `which python` train_imagenet.py \
--data-train=/data/ILSVRC2012_img_train.rec \
--data-val=/data/ILSVRC2012_img_val.rec \
--network=vgg \
--num-layers=16 \
--kv-store=dist_sync \
--gpus=0,1,2,3 \
--disp-batch=10 \
--top-k=5 \
--batch-size=128 \
--dtype=float32 \

a. The result after remove WaitToWrite:

INFO:root:Epoch[0] Batch [10]	Speed: 93.98 samples/sec	accuracy=0.001420	top_k_accuracy_5=0.003551
INFO:root:Epoch[0] Batch [10]	Speed: 89.04 samples/sec	accuracy=0.000000	top_k_accuracy_5=0.004261
INFO:root:Epoch[0] Batch [20]	Speed: 98.28 samples/sec	accuracy=0.001563	top_k_accuracy_5=0.005469

INFO:root:Epoch[0] Batch [60]	Speed: 94.82 samples/sec	accuracy=0.000000	top_k_accuracy_5=0.003906

The profile can be opened by chrome://tracing
@eric-haibin-lin
I found the way!
The file system is NTFS. I will try on another machine to check whether it's due to hardware reasons.

For problem 1, is removing this line safe? What if the data in `stored ` change during response?
For problem 2, in pull/push the same array is used for merging to guarantee the order. If `wait_to_write` is removed, I think previous pull might not finish.

For problem 1, before push finished, stored always WaitToRead. In sync model, pull will execute after all the push finished. At this time, I think  the data in stored won't change during response.
For problem 2, the data in previous pull were used in forward execute. The push execute after backward finished. I think when push execute, the previous pull must be finished .

I have tried on another machine, it still has the problem.  When I use read_idx() to read the rec, it will throw an error, however, when I use read() I checked that the unpacked label is correct with the *.lst file.
For problem 2, if "when push execute, the previous pull must be finished", I think `wait_to_write ` should return immediately every time.

Thanks for checking. I did not yet have time to try reproducing it, will do that next week. Could you tell me how big is the file by the way? Also, what is the version of MxNet you use (commit if compiled from source)?

The file size is about 55GB. I create the rec for Imagenet VID dataset following this https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/tree/master/example/ssd. The mxnet version is 0.11.0, installed with **pip install mxnet-cu80** on windows. Thanks.
But wait_to_write does't return immediately every time.With profile, we can find it locked until all the backward finished.
So I'm afraid that it waits `pull` finish. Right? @eric-haibin-lin
The fix looks good. Could you add a test in `tests/nightly/dist_sync_kvstore.py `, which tests `kv.pull ` right after `kv.init`? Also please sync with master branch. Thanks for the contribution!
closed for now...detected a bug in ps layer, need more investigation
Closing it due to inactivity
Based on #2248 moving `data_train.reset()` to the end of the epoch will resolve this issue.
specify `clip_gradient` in the optimizer also helps sometimes
@thinksanky would you host the changes somewhere so its effect can be inspected visually? Thanks.
Did you adjust the learning rate after it's "fixed" for a while?
Thanks ur solution got worked for me. Thanks and closing the issue.

No didn't change the learning rate. I retained the old framework which was used and only change I did replace resnetr 101 with resnet152 and  probing the weights at  appropriate places resnet152. Kindly suggest how to go ahead

I don't think this will automatically enable lapack when found.  The only action that gets performed here is setting LAPACK to 0, i.e. disabling it.  So this change is saying if LAPACK has been manually set to 1, don't reset it to 0 if your lapack lib happens to be in /usr/lib64.

For the linker search path, on my platform (Amazon Linux) /usr/lib64 is on the path.
nobody cares about cpp ?
check faster rcnn example in using prefix param. It might work for you.
